STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 30, 2025
Aprille Sutton
Child & Family Services of Northwestern Michigan
3785 Veterans Dr.
Traverse City, MI, 49684-4516
Re: License #: CB280201037
SI #: 2025SIC0000513
Dear Ms. Sutton:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 616-204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000513
Special Investigation Intake Date: March 31, 2025
License #: CB280201037
Licensee Group Organization: Child & Family Services of NW Michigan Inc
Licensee Designee: Aprille Sutton
Chief Administrator: Aprille Sutton
Agency Name: Child & Family Services of Northwestern
Michigan
Agency Address: 3785 VETERANS DR
TRAVERSE CITY, MI 49684-4516
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 04/04/2027
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
4/15/2025 2:31 PM Phone Interview
4/15/2025 12:49 PM Phone Other
4/11/2025 2:56 PM Phone Interview
4/4/2025 10:50 AM Email Documentation received or sent
4/3/2025 9:03 PM Email Documentation received or sent
4/3/2025 3:13 PM Phone Special Investigation Initiation,
Interview
4/1/2025 3:11 PM Phone Special Investigation Initiation
III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation; in person and family time
Section (1) An agency shall develop a plan of visitation and family time for
Description each child in foster care consistent with the child's service plans,
as required by R 400.12419 and R 400.12420 to ensure the safety
and well-being of the child.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The agency is not following the visitation plan. The caregiver
arrives late for scheduled parenting times, and the agency does
not extend the visitation for the parent and child.
Investigation Interviews:
Birthmother
On 4/3/2025 I interviewed Birthmother by telephone about the
allegations. Birthmother reported her son has been placed with
this agency since 1/7/2025. She reported she visits with her
children two times per week at the agency generally from 3:00pm
until 4:00pm. She reported the foster parents for Child A have
been late for her parent/child visits at least six times. The foster
parents’ lateness for the visits have ranged between 10 minutes to
40 minutes. The lateness of 40 minutes occurred one time; and
most lateness ranged between 10 minutes to about 15 minutes.
Birthmother reported she has requested her visits be extended the
amount of time the foster parents have been late, but this has not
always occurred. The agency has only made up at least 25
minutes of late time and that was with respect to the time the
foster parents were 45 minutes late for a visit.
Birthmother reported speaking with Foster Care Worker (FCW)
about the foster parents being late; the visits being extended on
1/16/2025 and most recently on 3/19/2025. She reported being
told by FCW that on occasions, the foster parents have not always
been late. That the foster parents/the child has been waiting in
the lobby, and by the time it has taken staff to retrieve Child A
and get him to the parent/child visitation area, the 10 or 15
minutes has transpired. Birthmother reported FCW does not
always supervise the parenting times and is relying on what others
have reported to her. Birthmother admitted she had discussed
foster parents lateness at the one FTM that has occurred; but the
foster parents were not involved, and she did not think they were
to be present for that. She does not believe anything has been
done to rectify making up for the several minutes that the foster
parents have been late. She has not spoken with a supervisor
about her concern. She did not know whether the agency has
asked the foster parents to stay over during the time they were
late; and the foster parents refused or were unable to do so. She
stated the agency has never talked about what they would do if
the foster parents are late. The agency has only stressed the
importance of her being on time for the visits.
Chief Administrator
2

I had an email correspondence with Chief Administrator (CA)
about the allegations on 4/4/2025. CA reported awareness of the
allegation and reported a special evaluation was being conducted
with the foster parents, Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2
pertaining to this issue.
Foster Care Worker
I interviewed Foster Care Worker (FCW) about this allegation by
telephone on 4/11/2025. FCW reported the agency received
responsibility for Birthmother and Child A’s, (an infant) case in
January of this year. She reported that the visitation plan set for
Birthmother is for Birthmother to receive two hours of visitation
twice per week. She reported the day of the week of
Birthmother’s visits varies due to Birthmother’s work schedule, but
the visits are normally during business hours. She reported there
are two children connected to the case; Child A whom Birthmother
has noted a concern about the foster parents; and Child B who is
placed with Child’ B’ father. FCW admitted there has been times
that Child A’s foster parents have been 10-15 minutes late for the
parent child visits; and on one occasion it was 45 minutes late.
FCW reported the one 45 minutes lateness was due to the foster
parents’ confusion about whether the visit was scheduled. As for
the times the foster parents were 10-15 minutes late, FCW was
not sure of the number of visits that occurred on, or whether those
were actually lateness by the foster parents or due to the foster
parents arriving timely and it taking a number of minutes to get the
child from the lobby to the visitation areas.
FCW reported it is the agency’s policy to extend visitation times
when foster parents are late. She reported visits are supervised by
a family support worker mostly, so she was not initially aware of
this issue. She reported one of Birthmother’s visits was extended
25 minutes following the time the foster parents were 40 minutes
late. Making up the other 15 minutes from that visit and making up
for the times the foster parents were supposably 10-15 minutes
late is in the works to be made up. FCW reported she had a
discussion with the foster parents about this when it was brought
to her attention by Birthmother in March; and her supervisor also
spoke with the foster parents. FCW said she has also spoken
with Birthmother about making up the missed visitation minutes.
She reported there is a community event activity coming up this
week where Birthmother can visit will get extra visitation time.
There is also a plan to extended Birthmother’s visitation by 25
minutes. FCW was not sure whether all of what she reported to
me was documented in her social work contacts; but reported the
children’s visitation plan is in the children’s service plan.
3

Foster Care Supervisor
On 4/15/2025, I interviewed Foster Care Supervisor (FCS) by
telephone about the allegations. She reported the matter of the
foster parents being late to visitation appointments was brought to
her attention on 3/20/2025. She affirmed FCW’s reporting about it
being agency policy to extend parent/child visit when foster
parents are late. She said the family support worker on this case
may not have been aware that the visits were to be extended
when foster parents are late. FCS reported that since this matter
was brought to her attention, she, the family support supervisor,
and the family support worker have addressed this matter, and
they are aware that Birthmother’s parent/child visitations are to be
extended by the few minutes the foster parents are late. She
reported Birthmother visitations are logged and there is
summarization by the family support worker or supervisor of the
visits. She provided me with copies of Birthmother’s visitation logs.
She reported the agency is continuing to work with Birthmother on
this matter. She also affirmed CA’s reporting that a special
evaluation by the agency’s licensing department was initiated with
Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 related to visitation issues.
Document Review
Child A’s and Child B’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
• Child B were removed from Birthmother’s care in August
2024; and Child A in December 2024. Child A remained in
the neonatal intensive care unit after his premature birth
until 1/7/2025, when he was placed with this agency.
• Both Child A and Child B are temporary court wards. Child
B has been placed with her father since 1/6/2025; and
Child A in Foster Parent 1’s and Foster Parent 2’s foster
home since 1/7/2025.
• Reunification with Birthmother is the permanency plan.
• An updated service plan for 1/23/2025- 4/22/2025 which
showed a discussion with the foster parents about arriving
late for parent/child visits; that Child A was late for one visit
on 3/12/2025 due to the transporter running late; and that
matter would be discussed with Birthmother.
• Child A and Child B parent/child visitation plan as being
supervised at the agency one hour per week twice weekly,
via one way glass; foster parents are to arrive on time and
bring back up items for the child, Birthmother is to arrive on
time and engage with the children.
4

Visitation Logs showing Birthmother’s visitation with Child A and
Child B from 1/15/2025 to 3/26/2025 which showed:
• Twice weekly one hour visitation times shown for
Birthmother with Child A and Child B, at varying visitation
hours prior to 5:00pm for dates prior to 3/3/2025. Though a
couple of those visits were two hours.
• Two-hour visits on 3/3/2025, 3/12/2025, 3/28/2025; and
3/26/2025 from 2:00pm-4:00pm
• Child A’s arrival time as 2:47pm on 1/16/2025 for a 2:00pm-
3:00pm scheduled visitation, and this visit went from
2:48pm-3:48pm.
• Child A’s arrival time as 1:45pm on 1/21/2025 for a
scheduled 1:00pm-2:00pm visit, and this visit went from
1:05pm (when Child B arrived) to 2:30pm.
• Child A’s arrival time as 3:15pm on 3/12/2025 for a
scheduled 2:00-4:00pm visit, and this visit went from
2:00pm-4:00pm.
• Child A’s arrival time as 3:15pm on 3/19/2025 for a
scheduled 2:00-4:00pm visit and this visit went from
2:00pm-4:00pm
• Child A’s arrival time as 3:15pm on 3/19/2025 for 2:00pm-
3:00pm and the visit going from 2:00pm-4:00pm
• Five other times where Child A’s arrival time was listed as
ranging from 2-10 minutes after the scheduled visitation
time; and the visit went longer for varying minutes on three
of those visits.
Foster Parent 1’s and Foster Parent 2’s CWLM record which
showed:
• A special evaluation was initiated on 3/31/2025 related to
allegations the foster parents were behaving in a manner
not consistent with being supportive of reunification;
including being consistently late for parent/child visitations
by at least 10 minutes causing the birth mother to lose time
with their child. The evaluation findings on this special
evaluation is pending.
Analysis Following interviews and case document reviews the evidence
showed there had been late arrival times by the foster parents to
Birthmother’s parent/child visits for Child A; and full visitation time
did not occur and have not all been made up. The evidence also
showed the agency is now addressing Birthmother’s concerns
around these missed minutes and reports it is working to make
them up. It was FCW’s responsibility to have been aware that
Birthmother was not receiving her full hour of visitation at each
visit prior to it being brought to her attention in March 2025.
5

Therein, the agency did not ensure for the parent/child visitation
plan developed for this family, and it is in violation of this rule.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan continuation of the agency
current license status is recommended.
May 23, 2025
______________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
May 23, 2025
